aBESAx-y6.memHandModelNotes:
Will use elevations below 490 m if local conditions are favorable (suitable stream flow accumulation in included Mus).

Matt E. used flow accumulation values 50-40,000 at elevations >548m & 50-10,000 at elevations <548m. Not sure if this will produce a result all that different from using fast only, but we could check. MJR 14feb07.

Added fresh water mapunit. Steve Williams 25jan08

Did not employ flow accumulation for this model. Removed hand modeling. MJR 4 March 2008.

references.A89CAM03NAUS: Camp, C. D., and D. G. Lovell. 1989. Fishing for "spring lizards":a technique for collecting blackbelly salamanders. Herpetol. Rev. 20:47.
references.A85BRU01NAUS: Bruce, R. C. 1985. Larval periods, population structure and the effects of stream drift in larvae of the salamanders DESMOGNATHUS QUADRAMACULATUS and LEUROGNATHUS MARMORATUS in a southern Appalachian stream. Copeia 1985:847-854.

references.B98PET01NCGP: Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.

references.B75CON01NAUS: Conant, R. 1975. A Field Guide to Reptiles and Amphibians of Eastern and Central North America. Second Edition. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston, Massachusetts. xvii + 429 pp.

references.A04CAM02USGP: Camp, C. D. 2004. Desmognathus folkertsi. Catalogue of American Amphibians and Reptiles 782:1-3.
references.B80MAR01NAUS: Martof, B. S., W. M. Palmer, J. R. Bailey, and J. R. Harrison, III. 1980. Amphibians and reptiles of the Carolinas and Virginia. University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, North Carolina. 264 pp.
references.A74VAL01NAUS: Valentine, B. D. 1974. Desmognathus quadramaculatus. Cat. Am. Amph. Rep. 153.1-153.4.

references.A02CAM01SEGP: Camp, C.D., S.G. Tilley, R.M Austin,  and J.L. Marshall. 2002. A new species of black-bellied salamander (genus Desmognathus) from the Appalacian mountains of northern Georgia. Herpetologica. 58:471-484.

references.A96CAS01SEGP: Castanet, J., H. Francillon-Vieillot, and R. C. Bruce. 1996. Age estimation in desmognathine salamanders assessed by skeletochronology. Herpetologica 52:160-171.

habitat_description: The Black-bellied salamander is found in the mountains and adjacent piedmont (Martof et al. 1980), generally at elevations above 500 m, to at least 1646 m, but may occur at lower elevations if conditions are suitable (Petranka 1998). Sympatric with recently described D. folkertsi at the southern end of the range (Camp et al. 2002). It is found in or along the banks of rocky, swift-moving streams with cool, clear water, near waterfalls and seeps.  Refuges are in rock crevices or in burrows (Camp and Lee 1996).  Usually found at elevations greater than 500 meters, but sometimes is found at lower elevations when local conditions are suitable (Petranka 1998).  Eggs are laid on undersides of rocks or on tree roots in streambed, apparently in headwater tributaries in North Carolina (Bruce 1985).  Lays up to about 60 eggs in June-July, singly or in cluster. The female remains with eggs until hatching. In Virginia, aquatic larvae hatched in August-September, metamorphosed in 2 years; larval period was 3-4 years (sometimes 2 years) in North Carolina (Bruce 1985, Bruce 1988). In northeastern Georgia, hatching occurred in July, and the larval period lasted 3 or 4 years, depending on location (Austin and Camp 1992). In North Carolina, females require at least 7-8 years to reach sexual maturity, males at least 6 years (Bruce 1988; Castanet et al. 1996).
